title: Measure your carbon footprint
content:
As more organizations embark on digital transformation initiatives, there is a growing need to balance innovation and sustainability. Increased IT resource consumption means increased energy consumption, which in turn results in increased CO2 emissions. Now it is critical for enterprises to consider both business transformation and environmental sustainability. 

The GreenOps solution is introduced to offer a range of features that deliver sustainable operations and help businesses achieve their environmental commitments. GreenOps aims to provide insights into your IT estate, enabling you to identify under/overconsumption and optimize capacity.

With this solution applied, you can enable the collection of spending, consumption, and carbon footprint data for cloud (AWS and Azure) and off-cloud IT assets - and deliver the report in a unified view. Through the carbon footprint report, you will be able to:

  • Identify and map sources of carbon in your IT ecosystem.
  • Analyze emissions across data centers and public clouds.

Ultimately, that means you can track your carbon emissions, identify opportunities for optimization, and monitor progress toward your sustainability goals.

Follow the instructions below to configure the carbon footprint feature settings and create your reports.

Prerequisites

For self-managed PostgreSQL databases, you need to check that there’re no error logs for the itom-carbon-footprint-deployment pod before enabling carbon footprint calculation. To do this, run the following command on a control plane node or the bastion node:

kubectl logs --tail=20 deploy/itom-carbon-footprint-deployment -c itom-carbon-footprint-deployment -n <namespace>

If you find errors in the output, see Error messages in carbon-footprint-deployment log for instructions.

Enable carbon footprint calculation

The carbon footprint feature is disabled by default. You may enable this feature from the Agent interface.

  1. Go to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings
  2. Turn on the Enable carbon footprint calculation feature.
    After this feature is enabled, the system will start the carbon footprint calculation at 0:00 AM.
  3. In the Start time of carbon footprint calculation field, set the month and the year when the carbon footprint calculation begins.
    Note that this setting is only used for cloud carbon footprint calculation. By default, the start time is set to the month the tenant was created.
  4. Save your changes.

ITAM infrastructures

You can manage your carbon emissions data for your IT asset management (ITAM) infrastructures.

Input carbon emissions data for asset models

When the asset model type is Device, Infrastructure & Peripheral, or Enterprise Asset, asset administrators can fill in carbon emissions data in the Sustainability section for the asset model.

  1. From the main menu, select Build >Service Asset & Configuration.
  2. From SACM Home, select Asset Models.
  3. Edit an asset model record.
  4. In the General > Sustainability section, input the carbon emissions data as required.
  5. Save your changes.

Input carbon emissions data for Device and Infrastructure & Peripheral records

For the Device and Infrastructure & Peripheral records, asset administrators can fill in carbon emissions data in the Sustainability section for the records:

  1. From the main menu, select Build > Service Asset & Configuration
  2. From SACM Home, select Infrastructure & Peripherals or Devices.
  3. Edit a device record or Edit an infrastructure & peripheral asset record.
  4. In the General > Overview section, input the usage location of your asset so that the carbon intensity of the location will be used for carbon emissions calculation. 
  5. In the General > Sustainability section, input the carbon emissions data as required.
  6. Save your changes.

Set carbon intensity of electricity based on location

The carbon emissions per kWh of electricity vary from country to country. You may set the carbon intensity of electricity based on each location:

  1. From the main menu, select Administration > Master Data > Locations.
  2. Update a location's details.
  3. In the Carbon intensity of electricity (kgCO2e/kWh) field, set the carbon emissions per kWh of electricity for this location.
  4. Save your changes.

Cloud infrastructures

You can manage your carbon emissions data for your cloud infrastructures.

View cloud carbon footprint calculation results 

On the 15th day of each month, the system will pull cloud usage data from Cloud Cost Reporting DB (AWS and Azure) and invoke the open-source CCF library (https://www.cloudcarbonfootprint.org/) to perform carbon footprint calculation for the last month. We also support carbon footprint calculation based on historical cloud usage data. You may set the calculation start time through Administration > Configuration > Application Settings > Start time of carbon footprint calculation.

After calculation, the carbon footprint result will be available in the following views in Cloud Cost Reporting DB. 
Note that as cloud carbon footprint is calculated based on the cloud usage data from Cloud Cost Reporting DB, if Cloud Cost Reporting is not enabled in your tenant, then no cloud carbon footprint will be available in your tenant.

View: CLOUD_AWS_CARBON_EMISSIONS_1M 

Field Description
timestamp The timestamp when the carbon emissions are generated
usage_account_id The account ID of the account that used this line item
region The geographical area that hosts your AWS services. Sample values: eu-west-3, us-west-1, us-east-1, ap-northeast-2, sa-east-1
service_name The name of the AWS service. Sample values: AmazonEC2, AmazonRDS, AmazonS3
kilowatt_hours Estimated energy based on usage data pulled from AWS
co2e Estimated greenhouse gas emissions expressed as carbon dioxide equivalents (metric tons CO2e) based on usage data pulled from AWS

View: CLOUD_AZURE_CARBON_EMISSIONS_1M

Field Description
timestamp The timestamp when the carbon emissions are generated
usage_account_id The Global Unique Identifier of your Azure subscription, which is a 32-digit GUID
usage_account_name Your Azure subscription name
region Identifies the data center where the meter is running. Sample values: EastUS2, CentralUS, westus2
service_name The name of the Azure platform service. Sample values: Storage, Virtual Machines, SQL Database
kilowatt_hours Estimated energy based on usage data pulled from Azure
co2e Estimated greenhouse gas emissions expressed as carbon dioxide equivalents (metric tons CO2e) based on usage data pulled from Azure

Create carbon footprint reports

You may create carbon footprint reports by several methods.

Create ITAM carbon footprint reports via OData

You may create an ITAM carbon footprint report via OData. For details, see Create carbon footprint report via OData.

Create cloud carbon footprint reports from Power BI

You may create a cloud carbon footprint report from Power BI. For details, see Create cloud carbon footprint reports from Power BI.

Download sample reports from Marketplace

You can also download the sample reports from OpenText marketplace.
